questions.text: Which of the following structures is not a part of the middle ear cleft?

options.label: A
options.text: Eustachian tube

options.label: B
options.text: Mastoid air cells

options.label: C
options.text: Aditus to mastoid antrum

options.label: D
options.text: Internal auditory canal

questions.correct_answer: D. Internal auditory canal
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Internal auditory canal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The middle ear cleft includes the Eustachian tube, middle ear cavity, aditus, mastoid antrum, and mastoid air cells.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 5
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 5

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the lateral wall of the middle ear is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It is formed by the round window

options.label: B
options.text: Scutum is located on the medial wall of the middle ear

options.label: C
options.text: Tympanic membrane forms the lateral wall of the middle ear

options.label: D
options.text: Scutum is part of the posterior wall of the middle ear

questions.correct_answer: C. Tympanic membrane forms the lateral wall of the middle ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tympanic membrane forms the lateral wall of the middle ear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lateral wall of the middle ear is formed by the tympanic membrane and the scutum, which is often eroded in cholesteatoma.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 5
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 5

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes MacEwen’s triangle, a key surgical landmark in mastoid surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: It is used to identify the facial recess, which lies 1.5 cm deep to it

options.label: B
options.text: It is bounded by the posterosuperior meatal wall, zygomatic arch, and sigmoid sinus

options.label: C
options.text: It helps identify the mastoid antrum, which lies approximately 1.5 cm deep to it

options.label: D
options.text: It is bordered superiorly by the parietal eminence and anteriorly by the Eustachian tube

questions.correct_answer: C. It helps identify the mastoid antrum, which lies approximately 1.5 cm deep to it
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It helps identify the mastoid antrum, which lies approximately 1.5 cm deep to it

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MacEwen’s triangle is a surface landmark bounded by the posterosuperior meatal wall, temporal line, and a posterior tangent to the external canal, used to identify the mastoid antrum located approximately 1.5 cm deep to it.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 5,6
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 5,6

questions.text: How is the stapes footplate attached to the oval window of the cochlea?

options.label: A
options.text: By fibrous bands at two points of contact

options.label: B
options.text: By the annular ligament circumferentially along its periphery

options.label: C
options.text: Through a direct bony fusion with the vestibule

options.label: D
options.text: By a fluid seal formed by the round window membrane

questions.correct_answer: B. By the annular ligament circumferentially along its periphery
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) By the annular ligament circumferentially along its periphery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The stapes footplate is attached to the oval window via the annular ligament in a circumferential manner, allowing sound transmission to the inner ear.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 86
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 86

questions.text: A patient develops sweating and flushing over the cheek while eating, following parotid gland surgery. Frey’s syndrome is suspected. Which of the following nerves is involved in the aberrant reinnervation responsible for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Chorda tympani

options.label: B
options.text: Auriculotemporal nerve

options.label: C
options.text: Greater auricular nerve

options.label: D
options.text: Nerve to mylohyoid

questions.correct_answer: B. Auriculotemporal nerve
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Auriculotemporal nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Frey’s syndrome results from aberrant regeneration of auriculotemporal nerve fibres that originally carried secretomotor supply to the parotid gland.
  • ➤ Parasympathetic pathway to the parotid gland :-
  • ➤ Parasympathetic pathway to the parotid gland :-
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 8
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 8

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the principle and interpretation of the Stenger test in a patient suspected of feigning unilateral hearing loss?

options.label: A
options.text: A patient with true unilateral deafness hears sound only in the affected ear when both ears are stimulated

options.label: B
options.text: A malingerer will deny hearing any sound when the stimulus is stronger in the "deaf" ear and weaker in the normal ear

options.label: C
options.text: The test is used to confirm bilateral conductive hearing loss using tuning forks of different frequencies

options.label: D
options.text: A positive Stenger test confirms the diagnosis of sensorineural hearing loss in both ears

questions.correct_answer: B. A malingerer will deny hearing any sound when the stimulus is stronger in the "deaf" ear and weaker in the normal ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A malingerer will deny hearing any sound when the stimulus is stronger in the "deaf" ear and weaker in the normal ear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Stenger test is used to detect unilateral malingering; if a patient denies hearing when a louder tone is presented to the "deaf" ear, it indicates feigned hearing loss (positive Stenger test).
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 22
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 22

questions.text: A 45yr old female presented with gradual onset progressive hearing loss in the right ear associated with pulsatile tinnitus. The tympanic membrane appeared reddish. TFT showed Rinne was negative on the right side, positive on the left and Weber lateralised to the right. Tinnitus temporarily ceased with carotid pressure and auscultation over mastoid revealed an audible bruit. Most likely diagnosis:

options.label: A
options.text: ASOM

options.label: B
options.text: Glomus Jugulare

options.label: C
options.text: Acoustic Neuroma

options.label: D
options.text: Otosclerosis

questions.correct_answer: B. Glomus Jugulare
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. ASOM (Acute Suppurative Otitis Media): This condition typically presents with rapid onset ear pain, fever, and hearing loss . The presentation of pulsatile tinnitus, a reddish tympanic membrane, and a bruit over the mastoid are not characteristic of ASOM.
  • • Option A. ASOM (Acute Suppurative Otitis Media):
  • • rapid onset
  • • ear pain, fever,
  • • hearing loss
  • • Option C. Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma): This is a benign tumor of the cranial nerve VIII ( vestibulocochlear nerve ). It typically presents with gradual hearing loss and tinnitus but does not produce a reddish tympanic membrane or an audible bruit. Also, acoustic neuroma usually causes sensorineural hearing loss, not conductive hearing loss.
  • • Option C. Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma):
  • • benign tumor
  • • cranial nerve VIII
  • • vestibulocochlear nerve
  • • gradual hearing loss
  • • tinnitus
  • • sensorineural hearing loss,
  • • Option D. Otosclerosis: Here, conductive hearing loss with intact tympanic membrane is noted but tinnitus is seen in only few people. And tinnitus, if present, is not pulsatile. Aquino sign is not seen here.
  • • Option D. Otosclerosis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glomus jugulare in patients presenting with pulsatile tinnitus, conductive hearing loss (as indicated by negative Rinne and lateralization of Weber to the affected side ), a reddish tympanic membrane , and an audible bruit over the mastoid .
  • ➤ Glomus jugulare
  • ➤ pulsatile tinnitus, conductive hearing loss
  • ➤ negative Rinne and lateralization of Weber
  • ➤ affected side
  • ➤ reddish tympanic membrane
  • ➤ audible bruit
  • ➤ mastoid
  • ➤ Ref : P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 109
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 109

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the galvanic test is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps differentiate cochlear from vestibular dysfunction

options.label: B
options.text: It is useful to localize lesions within the vestibular nerve versus end organ

options.label: C
options.text: The test is performed with the patient seated and eyes open

options.label: D
options.text: Normally, the patient sways away from the side of anodal stimulation

questions.correct_answer: B. It is useful to localize lesions within the vestibular nerve versus end organ
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It is useful to localize lesions within the vestibular nerve versus end organ

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The galvanic test is a vestibular assessment that helps differentiate end organ (labyrinthine) lesions from vestibular nerve lesions by evaluating postural sway in response to anodal stimulation.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 44
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 44

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding distraction techniques used in pediatric hearing assessment is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Distraction test is reliable only after 12 months of age when the child develops speech

options.label: B
options.text: It uses pure tone audiometry to assess hearing thresholds in infants

options.label: C
options.text: It is used around 6–7 months of age when the child begins to localize sound

options.label: D
options.text: Only high-frequency sounds are used, such as 8 kHz rattles or whistles

questions.correct_answer: C. It is used around 6–7 months of age when the child begins to localize sound
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is used around 6–7 months of age when the child begins to localize sound

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Distraction testing is performed at 6–7 months of age to assess hearing by observing the child’s head-turning response to various sound stimuli presented out of sight.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 118
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 118

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Threshold Tone Decay Test is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: A tone of 1000 Hz is presented at 20 dB above threshold for 60 seconds to assess cochlear pathology

options.label: B
options.text: A decay of more than 25 dB suggests a cochlear lesion

options.label: C
options.text: A tone of 4000 Hz is presented at 5 dB above threshold, and intensity is increased until the patient can hear it continuously for 60 seconds

options.label: D
options.text: The test is primarily used to assess the presence of middle ear pathology

questions.correct_answer: C. A tone of 4000 Hz is presented at 5 dB above threshold, and intensity is increased until the patient can hear it continuously for 60 seconds
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A tone of 4000 Hz is presented at 5 dB above threshold, and intensity is increased until the patient can hear it continuously for 60 seconds

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Threshold Tone Decay Test detects retrocochlear lesions by measuring how much above threshold a 4000 Hz tone must be presented for the patient to hear it continuously for 60 seconds.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 26
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 26

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the division of the vestibular system?

options.label: A
options.text: The central vestibular system includes the utricle, saccule, and semicircular ducts

options.label: B
options.text: The peripheral vestibular system is responsible for integrating impulses with other sensory systems

options.label: C
options.text: The central vestibular system includes vestibular nuclei and their connections within the CNS

options.label: D
options.text: The peripheral vestibular system includes the cochlea and auditory nerve

questions.correct_answer: C. The central vestibular system includes vestibular nuclei and their connections within the CNS
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The central vestibular system includes vestibular nuclei and their connections within the CNS

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The central vestibular system consists of vestibular nuclei and fibre tracts in the CNS, which integrate vestibular impulses to maintain body balance.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 17
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 17

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly explains the importance of phase differential between the oval and round windows in the auditory system?

options.label: A
options.text: Sound waves reach both oval and round windows simultaneously to enhance perilymph vibration

options.label: B
options.text: Ossicular chain delivers sound preferentially to the round window for cochlear stimulation

options.label: C
options.text: Phase differential ensures compression at the oval window coincides with compression at the round window

options.label: D
options.text: Phase differential prevents cancellation of waves and ensures perilymph movement by offsetting compression and rarefaction

questions.correct_answer: D. Phase differential prevents cancellation of waves and ensures perilymph movement by offsetting compression and rarefaction
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Phase differential prevents cancellation of waves and ensures perilymph movement by offsetting compression and rarefaction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phase differential between the oval and round windows ensures alternate compression and rarefaction, preventing cancellation of waves and enabling perilymph movement for effective hearing.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 13.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 13.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the physiological basis for body equilibrium?

options.label: A
options.text: Visual input is the only component responsible for body balance in static posture

options.label: B
options.text: The vestibular system acts independently and is unaffected by somatosensory inputs

options.label: C
options.text: Body equilibrium is maintained by a push-pull system between bilateral vestibular inputs, corrected by reflexes like vestibulo-ocular and vestibulospinal

options.label: D
options.text: Loss of equilibrium is only seen during rapid movement, not in static imbalance

questions.correct_answer: C. Body equilibrium is maintained by a push-pull system between bilateral vestibular inputs, corrected by reflexes like vestibulo-ocular and vestibulospinal
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Body equilibrium is maintained by a push-pull system between bilateral vestibular inputs, corrected by reflexes like vestibulo-ocular and vestibulospinal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Equilibrium is maintained by a bilateral vestibular push-pull system integrated with visual and somatosensory input, corrected by reflexes like vestibulo-ocular and vestibulospinal responses.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 18
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 18

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Short Increment Sensitivity Index (SISI) test is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: SISI score is typically high in retrocochlear lesions like vestibular schwannoma

options.label: B
options.text: The test uses a continuous tone presented at threshold level with 5 dB increments

options.label: C
options.text: A SISI score between 70–100% is highly suggestive of cochlear pathology

options.label: D
options.text: Conductive hearing loss usually shows a SISI score above 70%

questions.correct_answer: C. A SISI score between 70–100% is highly suggestive of cochlear pathology
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A SISI score between 70–100% is highly suggestive of cochlear pathology

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A SISI score of 70–100% is indicative of cochlear pathology , helping differentiate it from retrocochlear and conductive causes of hearing loss.
  • ➤ cochlear pathology
  • ➤ retrocochlear
  • ➤ conductive
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 26
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 26

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Autoimmune Inner Ear Disease (AIED) is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: AIED typically presents with sudden, unilateral conductive hearing loss

options.label: B
options.text: Methotrexate is the first-line treatment for all patients diagnosed with AIED

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of anti-heat shock protein 70 (anti-Hsp70) antibodies may correlate with steroid responsiveness

options.label: D
options.text: Progression is defined as a threshold shift of 5 dB at any frequency on follow-up audiograms

questions.correct_answer: C. Presence of anti-heat shock protein 70 (anti-Hsp70) antibodies may correlate with steroid responsiveness
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Presence of anti-heat shock protein 70 (anti-Hsp70) antibodies may correlate with steroid responsiveness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Presence of anti-Hsp70 antibodies in autoimmune inner ear disease may correlate with active disease and steroid responsiveness, aiding in diagnosis and treatment planning.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 36
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 36

questions.text: Which of the following findings during a Hallpike manoeuvre is most suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) due to a peripheral cause?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate onset of nystagmus, direction changing, non-fatiguable

options.label: B
options.text: Nystagmus with no vertigo and variable direction in each head position

options.label: C
options.text: Nystagmus with 2–20 second latency, fixed direction toward the undermost ear, and fatiguable

options.label: D
options.text: Nystagmus lasting over 1 minute, present in straight head-hanging position only

questions.correct_answer: C. Nystagmus with 2–20 second latency, fixed direction toward the undermost ear, and fatiguable
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nystagmus with 2–20 second latency, fixed direction toward the undermost ear, and fatiguable

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ BPPV is indicated by nystagmus with a latency of 2–20 seconds, fixed direction toward the undermost ear, and fatiguability on repeated Hallpike manoeuvre testing.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 42
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 42

questions.text: Which of the following findings is most consistent with midline cerebellar dysfunction?

options.label: A
options.text: Adiadochokinesia and abnormal finger–nose test

options.label: B
options.text: Dysmetria and rebound phenomenon

options.label: C
options.text: Truncal ataxia and wide-based gait

options.label: D
options.text: Hemiplegia with spasticity and positive Babinski sign

questions.correct_answer: C. Truncal ataxia and wide-based gait
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Truncal ataxia and wide-based gait

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Midline cerebellar dysfunction typically presents with truncal ataxia, wide-based gait, falls in any direction, and difficulty turning while walking.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 42
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 42

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding cochlear function and auditory transduction is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: All frequencies stimulate the entire length of the basilar membrane uniformly

options.label: B
options.text: Shearing between basilar and tectorial membranes distorts hair cells, initiating cochlear microphonics

options.label: C
options.text: Low-frequency sounds stimulate the basal turn of the cochlea, while high frequencies reach the apex

options.label: D
options.text: The primary auditory neurons are multipolar and located in the cochlear nuclei

questions.correct_answer: B. Shearing between basilar and tectorial membranes distorts hair cells, initiating cochlear microphonics
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Shearing between basilar and tectorial membranes distorts hair cells, initiating cochlear microphonics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Shearing between the basilar and tectorial membranes distorts hair cells, generating cochlear microphonics and initiating auditory transduction based on frequency-specific displacement along the basilar membrane.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 13
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 13

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Visual Reinforcement Audiometry (VRA) is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: VRA is best suited for children above 3 years of age

options.label: B
options.text: VRA involves conditioning the child to turn toward sound, reinforced by visual stimuli like flashing lights or animated toys

options.label: C
options.text: VRA uses only bone conduction testing as headphones are not well tolerated by infants

options.label: D
options.text: VRA cannot determine hearing thresholds using standard audiometric techniques

questions.correct_answer: B. VRA involves conditioning the child to turn toward sound, reinforced by visual stimuli like flashing lights or animated toys
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) VRA involves conditioning the child to turn toward sound, reinforced by visual stimuli like flashing lights or animated toys

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Visual Reinforcement Audiometry (VRA) is used in children aged 6 months to 2 years to assess hearing by conditioning head-turning responses to sound, reinforced with visual stimuli.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 118
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 118

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the cold-air caloric test is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It is preferred over water caloric testing in patients with intact tympanic membranes

options.label: B
options.text: It uses warm air to stimulate the cochlear portion of the inner ear

options.label: C
options.text: It is contraindicated in tympanic membrane perforation

options.label: D
options.text: It is a qualitative vestibular test using cooled air through a Dundas Grant tube

questions.correct_answer: D. It is a qualitative vestibular test using cooled air through a Dundas Grant tube
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) It is a qualitative vestibular test using cooled air through a Dundas Grant tube

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cold-air caloric test is a qualitative vestibular test used when the tympanic membrane is perforated, utilizing cooled air delivered through a Dundas Grant tube.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 43
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 43

questions.text: Based on the development timeline of ear structures, which of the following completes its development latest during fetal life?

options.label: A
options.text: Pinna

options.label: B
options.text: External auditory meatus

options.label: C
options.text: Cochlea

options.label: D
options.text: Middle ear

questions.correct_answer: D. Middle ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Middle ear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Among the ear structures, the middle ear completes its development last—by the 30th week of gestation.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 12
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 12

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the auditory neural pathway is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Spiral ganglion is located in the modiolus of the cochlea and contains multipolar neurons

options.label: B
options.text: The auditory cortex is located in the inferior frontal gyrus (Brodmann area 4)

options.label: C
options.text: Each ear is represented only in the contralateral cerebral hemisphere

options.label: D
options.text: The axons of bipolar neurons in the spiral ganglion form the cochlear nerve and terminate in the dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei

questions.correct_answer: D. The axons of bipolar neurons in the spiral ganglion form the cochlear nerve and terminate in the dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The axons of bipolar neurons in the spiral ganglion form the cochlear nerve and terminate in the dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cochlear nerve arises from bipolar neurons in the spiral ganglion and projects to the dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei, with the auditory pathway ascending bilaterally through E. COLI-MA to the auditory cortex in Brodmann area 41.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 13.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 13.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of the Eustachian tube?

options.label: A
options.text: Clearance of middle ear secretions via mucociliary action

options.label: B
options.text: Protection of middle ear from nasopharyngeal pressure and secretions

options.label: C
options.text: Equalization of pressure across tympanic membrane

options.label: D
options.text: Continuous drainage of perilymph from the inner ear

questions.correct_answer: D. Continuous drainage of perilymph from the inner ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Continuous drainage of perilymph from the inner ear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Eustachian tube ventilates the middle ear, protects it from nasopharyngeal secretions and pressure, and clears secretions via mucociliary action.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 58
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 58

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the comparison between canal wall up and canal wall down mastoidectomy procedures?

options.label: A
options.text: Canal wall up procedure has a lower rate of residual disease and does not require a second-look surgery

options.label: B
options.text: Canal wall down procedure provides a normal meatal appearance and allows unrestricted swimming

options.label: C
options.text: Canal wall up procedure preserves a normal meatus and is better suited for patients requiring hearing aids

options.label: D
options.text: Canal wall down procedure requires second-look surgery to rule out cholesteatoma recurrence

questions.correct_answer: C. Canal wall up procedure preserves a normal meatus and is better suited for patients requiring hearing aids
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Canal wall up procedure preserves a normal meatus and is better suited for patients requiring hearing aids

questions.text: Which of the following signs and symptoms are not true with the respective stage of Acute Suppurative Otitis Media?

options.label: A
options.text: Suppuration – Excruciating Earache, Deafness and Bulging TM with pus, CHL

options.label: B
options.text: PreSuppuration – Throbbing Pain, Deafness and Cartwheel TM, CHL

options.label: C
options.text: Resolution – Ear Discharge and patient starts to feel Better, Perforation in Antero-Inferior Quadrant, CHL improves

options.label: D
options.text: All above options are correct

questions.correct_answer: D. All above options are correct
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All above options are correct

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Suppuration Stage: During this stage of Acute Suppurative Otitis Media (ASOM), there is typically excruciating earache , hearing loss (deafness) , and a bulging tympanic membrane (TM) with visible pus . The hearing loss in this case is usually conductive hearing loss (CHL) due to the middle ear being filled with pus , which hinders the movement of the TM and the ossicles.
  • • Option A
  • • Suppuration Stage:
  • • stage
  • • Acute Suppurative Otitis Media
  • • typically excruciating earache
  • • hearing loss (deafness)
  • • bulging tympanic membrane (TM)
  • • visible pus
  • • hearing loss
  • • conductive hearing loss (CHL)
  • • middle ear
  • • filled with pus
  • • hinders
  • • Option B . Presuppuration Stage : This stage precedes the suppuration and is characterized by throbbing ear pain and deafness . The TM often appears red and inflamed , sometimes described as a "cartwheel" appearance , and there is usually CHL due to the Eustachian tube dysfunction and the accumulation of fluid in the middle ear.
  • • Option B
  • • Presuppuration Stage
  • • precedes
  • • suppuration
  • • characterized by
  • • throbbing ear pain
  • • deafness
  • • red
  • • inflamed
  • • "cartwheel" appearance
  • • usually CHL
  • • Eustachian tube dysfunction
  • • accumulation of fluid
  • • Option C . Resolution Stage : In the resolution stage, the patient often starts to feel better , and there might be ear discharge due to the perforation of the TM . The perforation is typically seen in the antero-inferior quadrant . With the release of pus through the perforation, the pressure in the middle ear decreases , leading to an improvement in CHL .
  • • Option C
  • • Resolution Stage
  • • starts to feel better
  • • ear discharge
  • • perforation of the TM
  • • antero-inferior quadrant
  • • release of pus
  • • through
  • • pressure
  • • middle ear decreases
  • • leading
  • • improvement in CHL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The progression of Acute Suppurative Otitis Media through different stages - tubal occlusion (retracted TM, mild ear pain & block), presuppuration ( throbbing pain, deafness, cartwheel TM appearance, CHL ), suppuration ( excruciating earache, deafness, bulging TM with pus, CHL ), and resolution (ear discharge, improvement in symptoms, perforation in the antero-inferior quadrant of TM, improvement in CHL).
  • ➤ progression
  • ➤ Acute Suppurative Otitis Media
  • ➤ tubal occlusion (retracted TM, mild ear pain & block), presuppuration
  • ➤ throbbing pain, deafness, cartwheel TM appearance, CHL
  • ➤ suppuration
  • ➤ excruciating earache, deafness, bulging TM with pus, CHL
  • ➤ resolution (ear discharge, improvement in symptoms, perforation in the antero-inferior quadrant of TM, improvement in CHL).
  • ➤ Ref : P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 62, 63
  • ➤ Ref : P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 62, 63

questions.correct_answer: C. Serous Otitis Media
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Serous Otitis Media

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . In ASOM, the tympanic membrane typically appears red and bulging due to the presence of pus in the middle ear . It is associated with acute infection and symptoms such as ear pain, fever , and possibly otorrhea if perforation occurs. The image does not show these features.

  • • possibly otorrhea
  • • Option B . CSOM is characterized by persistent ear discharge through a perforated tympanic membrane and a long-standing infection . The tympanic membrane may show granulation tissue or a visible perforation . The image does not show signs of active discharge or perforation.
  • • Option B
  • • persistent ear discharge
  • • perforated tympanic membrane
  • • long-standing infection
  • • show granulation tissue
  • • visible perforation
  • • Option D . This condition is characterized by a retracted tympanic membrane that has become thin and atrophic , causing it to adhere to the ossicles and/or inner ear structures . The image shows a retracted tympanic membrane with a parchment-like appearance and scarring , which are hallmarks of adhesive otitis media .
  • • Option D

questions.text: A 6-yr-old child presents with recurrent URTI with mouth breathing and failure to grow with high arched palate and impaired hearing. His tympanogram showed b type curve. He should be managed by

options.label: A
options.text: Myringotomy

options.label: B
options.text: Myringotomy + Grommet Insertion

options.label: C
options.text: Grommet Insertion only

options.label: D
options.text: Adenoidectomy + Grommet Insertion

questions.correct_answer: D. Adenoidectomy + Grommet Insertion
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Adenoidectomy + Grommet Insertion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Myringotomy involves making an incision in the tympanic membrane to relieve pressure and drain fluid . While it can provide temporary relief , it does not address the underlying problem of Eustachian tube dysfunction, which is likely in this case given the recurrent upper respiratory tract infections (URTI) and mouth breathing.
  • • Option A
  • • making an incision
  • • tympanic membrane
  • • relieve pressure
  • • drain fluid
  • • provide temporary relief
  • • Option B. Myringotomy with grommet insertion would address the middle ear effusion as evidenced by the type B tympanogram (indicative of fluid in the middle ear ), but it may not be enough if there is significant adenoid hypertrophy contributing to Eustachian tube dysfunction and recurrent URTIs.
  • • Option B.
  • • address the middle ear effusion
  • • evidenced
  • • type B tympanogram
  • • fluid in the middle ear
  • • Option C . Grommet insertion alone would address the middle ear effusion and associated hearing impairment , but it would not treat the probable adenoid hypertrophy that is causing mouth breathing and recurrent URTIs.
  • • Option C
  • • address the middle ear effusion
  • • associated hearing impairment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a child with recurrent URTIs, mouth breathing , and a type B tympanogram , adenoid hypertrophy is a likely contributing factor. Thus, management should include both adenoidectomy to address the adenoid hypertrophy and grommet insertion to resolve the middle ear effusion and associated hearing loss .
  • ➤ child with recurrent URTIs, mouth breathing
  • ➤ type B tympanogram
  • ➤ adenoid hypertrophy
  • ➤ both adenoidectomy
  • ➤ address
  • ➤ adenoid hypertrophy
  • ➤ grommet insertion
  • ➤ resolve
  • ➤ middle ear effusion
  • ➤ associated hearing loss
  • ➤ Ref : P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 65
  • ➤ Ref : P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 65

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset vertigo, nausea, and hearing loss in his right ear following a deep scuba diving session earlier in the day. He denies any recent upper respiratory infections, otalgia, or discharge from the ear. On examination, you note horizontal nystagmus and a negative Rinne test on the affected side. The tympanic membrane is intact without signs of inflammation or effusion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Meniere's disease

options.label: B
options.text: Acoustic neuroma

options.label: C
options.text: Perilymph fistula

options.label: D
options.text: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV)

questions.correct_answer: C. Perilymph fistula
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Perilymph fistula

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Meniere's disease typically presents with episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and a feeling of fullness in the ear . These episodes can last from 20 minutes to several hours , not typically associated with diving or immediate onset after a pressure change.
  • • Option A. Meniere's disease
  • • episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and a feeling of fullness in the ear
  • • 20 minutes to several hours
  • • Option B. Acoustic neuroma is a benign tumor of the cranial nerve VIII (vestibulocochlear nerve) that usually presents with progressive unilateral hearing loss , tinnitus , and sometimes balance disturbances. Its onset is gradual, not sudden after an event like diving.
  • • Option B. Acoustic neuroma
  • • benign tumor
  • • cranial nerve VIII
  • • progressive unilateral hearing loss
  • • tinnitus
  • • balance disturbances.
  • • Option D. Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is characterized by brief episodes of vertigo related to head position changes . It is caused by dislodged otoliths moving into one of the semicircular canals , leading to inappropriate stimulation of the vestibular system . There's typically no hearing loss associated with BPPV.
  • • Option D. Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV)
  • • brief episodes of vertigo
  • • head position changes
  • • dislodged otoliths
  • • semicircular canals
  • • inappropriate stimulation of the vestibular system

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Perilymph fistula is a cause of sudden onset vertigo and hearing loss following a pressure-altering event , distinguished by the absence of tympanic membrane inflammation or effusion , and negative findings for other causes of vertigo and hearing loss .
  • ➤ Perilymph fistula
  • ➤ sudden onset vertigo
  • ➤ hearing loss
  • ➤ pressure-altering event
  • ➤ absence of tympanic membrane inflammation or effusion
  • ➤ negative findings
  • ➤ vertigo and hearing loss

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of vertigo, particularly when she turns her head quickly. To assess her vestibular function, the physician decides to perform a Fitzgerald-Hallpike bithermal caloric test. Which of the following outcomes of this test is considered normal?

options.label: A
options.text: Absence of nystagmus with both warm and cold water irrigation

options.label: B
options.text: Direction-changing nystagmus with warm water irrigation in the left ear and cold water irrigation in the right ear

options.label: C
options.text: Nystagmus beating toward the irrigated ear with warm water and away from the irrigated ear with cold water

options.label: D
options.text: Stronger nystagmus with cold water irrigation than with warm water irrigation in both ears

questions.correct_answer: C. Nystagmus beating toward the irrigated ear with warm water and away from the irrigated ear with cold water
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nystagmus beating toward the irrigated ear with warm water and away from the irrigated ear with cold water

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Absence of nystagmus with both warm and cold water irrigation: This outcome is abnormal . The normal response to caloric testing involves the induction of nystagmus , which is a rapid, involuntary movement of the eyes . The absence of nystagmus may indicate a vestibular dysfunction.
  • • Option A. Absence of nystagmus with both warm and cold water irrigation:
  • • abnormal
  • • normal response to caloric testing
  • • induction of nystagmus
  • • rapid, involuntary movement of the eyes
  • • Option B. Direction-changing nystagmus with warm water irrigation in the left ear and cold water irrigation in the right ear: While nystagmus direction can change based on the ear being irrigated and the temperature of the water , this option does not accurately describe the expected directional pattern for a normal response.
  • • Option B. Direction-changing nystagmus with warm water irrigation in the left ear and cold water irrigation in the right ear:
  • • nystagmus direction
  • • ear being irrigated and the temperature of the water
  • • Option D. Stronger nystagmus with cold water irrigation than with warm water irrigation in both ears: The strength of nystagmus is not the primary indicator of a normal response in the caloric test . The direction of the nystagmus in relation to the ear being irrigated and the temperature of the water is more relevant.
  • • Option D. Stronger nystagmus with cold water irrigation than with warm water irrigation in both ears:
  • • strength of nystagmus
  • • not the primary indicator of a normal response
  • • caloric test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Fitzgerald-Hallpike bithermal caloric test evaluates vestibular function by inducing nystagmus through the irrigation of the external auditory canal with warm and cold water . The normal response is nystagmus that beats toward the irrigated ear with warm water and away with cold water.
  • ➤ Fitzgerald-Hallpike bithermal caloric test
  • ➤ vestibular function by inducing nystagmus through the irrigation of the external auditory canal
  • ➤ warm and cold water

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the indications for hearing aid use is correct?

options.label: A

options.label: C
options.text: Conductive hearing loss is not treated with hearing aids under any circumstance

options.label: D
options.text: Hearing aids are delayed in deaf children until after 5 years of age to assess speech development

questions.correct_answer: A. Hearing aids are recommended for individuals with hearing loss that cannot be corrected by medical or surgical means
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hearing aids are recommended for individuals with hearing loss that cannot be corrected by medical or surgical means

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hearing aids are indicated for individuals with hearing loss that cannot be corrected by medical or surgical treatment.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 121
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 121

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding hyperkinetic disorders of the facial nerve?

options.label: A
options.text: Blepharospasm usually affects only one eye and is most commonly caused by acoustic neuroma

options.label: B
options.text: Botulinum toxin is ineffective in hemifacial spasm but useful in treating exposure keratitis

options.label: C
options.text: Hemifacial spasm can be caused by a vascular loop compressing the facial nerve at the cerebellopontine angle

options.label: D
options.text: Selective nerve section is contraindicated in the treatment of essential hemifacial spasm and blepharospasm

questions.correct_answer: C. Hemifacial spasm can be caused by a vascular loop compressing the facial nerve at the cerebellopontine angle
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hemifacial spasm can be caused by a vascular loop compressing the facial nerve at the cerebellopontine angle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hemifacial spasm may be caused by a vascular loop compressing the facial nerve at the cerebellopontine angle and is treatable by microvascular decompression or botulinum toxin.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 103–104.
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 103–104.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding transverse fractures of the temporal bone?

options.label: A
options.text: Most commonly caused by parietal blows and associated with conductive hearing loss

options.label: B
options.text: Often associated with bleeding from the ear and injury to ossicles

options.label: C
options.text: Involve sensorineural hearing loss and immediate facial paralysis in most cases

options.label: D
options.text: Characterized by CSF otorrhea that is usually mixed with blood

questions.correct_answer: C. Involve sensorineural hearing loss and immediate facial paralysis in most cases
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Involve sensorineural hearing loss and immediate facial paralysis in most cases

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transverse temporal bone fractures typically cause sensorineural hearing loss and immediate facial paralysis due to injury to the labyrinth or proximal facial nerve.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 100–101.
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 100–101.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about causes of tinnitus is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Objective tinnitus is most commonly psychogenic and occurs without any identifiable physical source

options.label: B
options.text: Venous hum and vascular lesions like glomus tumors are typical causes of subjective tinnitus

options.label: C
options.text: Clicking tinnitus due to palatal myoclonus is an example of subjective tinnitus that occurs during swallowing

options.label: D
options.text: Abnormally patent eustachian tube and palatal myoclonus can cause objective tinnitus synchronized with respiration or muscle contractions

questions.correct_answer: D. Abnormally patent eustachian tube and palatal myoclonus can cause objective tinnitus synchronized with respiration or muscle contractions
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Abnormally patent eustachian tube and palatal myoclonus can cause objective tinnitus synchronized with respiration or muscle contractions

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Objective tinnitus may result from physical sources like palatal myoclonus or a patulous eustachian tube, producing sounds synchronized with muscle activity or respiration.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 130
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 130

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding surgical management of facial nerve injury?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypoglossal-facial anastomosis restores facial movement without any impact on tongue function

options.label: B
options.text: End-to-end anastomosis is preferred when the nerve gap is large and requires tension to bridge

options.label: C
options.text: Cable grafting is used when the gap between severed nerve ends is too large for direct anastomosis

options.label: D
options.text: Decompression involves rerouting the entire facial nerve to relieve mechanical pressure

questions.correct_answer: C. Cable grafting is used when the gap between severed nerve ends is too large for direct anastomosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cable grafting is used when the gap between severed nerve ends is too large for direct anastomosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cable grafting is indicated when the gap between severed facial nerve ends is too large to allow tension-free end-to-end anastomosis.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 105.
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 105.

questions.text: During middle ear surgery, which of the following correctly describes a key surgical landmark for identifying the facial nerve?

options.label: A
options.text: The facial nerve lies lateral to the short process of incus at the level of aditus

options.label: B
options.text: The facial nerve runs behind the pyramid and posterior tympanic sulcus

options.label: C
options.text: The tympanic segment of the facial nerve starts at the posterior end of the digastric ridge

options.label: D
options.text: The geniculate ganglion is located posterior to the processus cochleariformis

questions.correct_answer: B. The facial nerve runs behind the pyramid and posterior tympanic sulcus
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The facial nerve runs behind the pyramid and posterior tympanic sulcus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The facial nerve runs behind the pyramid and posterior tympanic sulcus in its vertical (mastoid) segment, serving as a key landmark in middle ear surgery.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 96.
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 96.

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the labyrinthine segment of the facial nerve?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the longest segment of the facial nerve and lies within the internal acoustic meatus

options.label: B
options.text: It extends from the geniculate ganglion to the stylomastoid foramen

options.label: C
options.text: It is the shortest and narrowest segment, making it vulnerable to compression-related paralysis

options.label: D
options.text: It lies below the oval window and lateral semicircular canal

questions.correct_answer: C. It is the shortest and narrowest segment, making it vulnerable to compression-related paralysis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is the shortest and narrowest segment, making it vulnerable to compression-related paralysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The labyrinthine segment of the facial nerve is the shortest and narrowest portion, making it highly susceptible to compression-induced facial paralysis.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 90
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 90

questions.text: Which of the following statements about CROS (Contralateral Routing of Signals) hearing aids is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: CROS aids use a bone conduction oscillator placed on the mastoid of the deaf ear

options.label: B
options.text: CROS aids are primarily used in bilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss

options.label: C
options.text: CROS aids deliver sound from the better ear to the poorer ear for improved clarity

options.label: D
options.text: CROS aids transmit sound from the deaf ear to the better ear to improve sound awareness on the deaf side

questions.correct_answer: D. CROS aids transmit sound from the deaf ear to the better ear to improve sound awareness on the deaf side
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) CROS aids transmit sound from the deaf ear to the better ear to improve sound awareness on the deaf side

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CROS hearing aids route sound from the deaf ear to the better ear, helping with sound localization in cases of single-sided deafness.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 122
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ P.L. Dhingra – Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Ed., pg. 122

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with pulsatile tinnitus and conductive hearing loss. Otoscopy reveals a reddish mass behind the intact tympanic membrane that blanches on applying pressure with Siegel’s speculum. Which of the following is true regarding her likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Biopsy is the investigation of choice to confirm glomus tympanicum

options.label: B
options.text: CT scan shows salt and pepper appearance due to tumor vascularity

options.label: C
options.text: Most glomus tumors are functional and secrete catecholamines

options.label: D
options.text: The tumor most likely arises from the promontory and receives blood from the ascending pharyngeal artery

questions.correct_answer: D. The tumor most likely arises from the promontory and receives blood from the ascending pharyngeal artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The tumor most likely arises from the promontory and receives blood from the ascending pharyngeal artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glomus tympanicum is a highly vascular middle ear tumor arising from the promontory, often in females, presenting with pulsatile tinnitus, and is fed by the inferior tympanic branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery; biopsy is contraindicated.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 109
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 109

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the chorda tympani nerve is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a branch of glossopharyngeal nerve that enters the middle ear through the Eustachian tube

options.label: B
options.text: It runs lateral to the tympanic membrane between the incus and the stapes

options.label: C
options.text: It carries secretomotor fibres to the parotid gland and taste fibres from posterior one-third of tongue

options.label: D
options.text: It carries taste from anterior two-thirds of tongue and passes between handle of malleus and long process of incus

questions.correct_answer: D. It carries taste from anterior two-thirds of tongue and passes between handle of malleus and long process of incus
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) It carries taste from anterior two-thirds of tongue and passes between handle of malleus and long process of incus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chorda tympani is a branch of facial nerve that carries taste from anterior two-thirds of tongue and secretomotor fibres to submandibular/sublingual glands, running between the handle of malleus and long process of incus.
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 8
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 8
